Stocks probed new lows of the day in early Friday afternoon action. Investors fretted Britain's decision to leave the European Union, prompting worries about the future of free trade between the island nation and the continent, as well as the future political and economic stability of the EU itself.Meanwhile, Apple (AAPL) was trimming its losses and faring better than the Nasdaq composite, down 2.6% to 93.59 vs. a more than 3.6% slide for the latter. However, the gap down in heavy trading pushed the iPhone and iMac computer maker back near its calendar-year low of 89.47.The Nasdaq 100 practically matched the Nasdaq composite losses, down 3.4%. The index tracking the 100 largest nonfinancial companies is on pace to match its 3.8% plunge on Aug. 24, 2015, known as the August flash crash.The S&P 500 slid 2.9%, near the lows of the session, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.7%. Small caps fared worse, with the Russell 2000 off 3.5%. Money flowed into the defensive utility sector, as the Dow utility average romped more than 1% higher before giving back some of that gain. Volume ballooned higher vs. the same time on Thursday, boosted in part by the scheduled rebalancing of the Russell equity indexes.Only a sliver of names in the IBD 50 showed a gain in the stock market today, including WEC Energy (WEC). The Milwaukee-based diversified utility gained more than 1.3% to 63.63. The stock has rallied nearly 17% after clearing a 54.45 handle entry within a long saucer base on Jan. 28. Tobacco firm Reynolds American (RAI), featured in IBD's Income Investor column on Wednesday, rose nearly 2% to 51.80, nearing a 51.64 flat-base buy point.Apple is now almost 30% below a 52-week peak of 132.97, making the current decline one of the most severe in the stock since it sank 45% from a 100.75 high in September 2012 to a low of 55.03 in April 2013. Apple shares eventually rebounded and rallied to all-time highs, as both the market and economy showed strength in 2013 and 2014. However, today the consumer electronics titan faces regulatory challenges and intense competition in China, one of its top new markets.A rebound by Apple that is strong enough to carry the stock back above its still-falling 10- and 40-week moving averages would indicate that investors see a return to increasing sales and earnings. Yet for now, the Street sees profit shrinking 10% to $8.26 a share in fiscal 2016, which ends in September.Apple is not the only big-cap tech that's struggling below its 50- and 200-day support lines.German business software giant SAP (SAP) gapped down below its 200-day moving average as it fell more than 7% to 74.84. Investors perhaps are showing concern about SAP's future ability to do business in the U.K. In the first quarter of this year, SAP had logged its first quarterly double-digit gains in earnings and revenue for the first time in more than four years.Microsoft (MSFT) fell 3.9% to 49.89, sinking back below its 50- and 200-day lines. The stock is back near the bottom of a new basing pattern.As seen in Thursday's Big Picture column and Market Pulse table, the market's current outlook was revised back to "confirmed uptrend" from "uptrend under pressure." However, the big sell-off in the wake of Britain's decision to exit the European Union affirms that market volatility remains high. While an investor can still buy stocks that break out from properly formed bases, the probability of making money is lower than normal, even if the Nasdaq composite saw its distribution day count (denoting heavy selling) on Wednesday fall to 3.Is your stock is best in class within its industry group in terms of profit growth, margins, sales, return on equity, institutional fund sponsorship and relative price strength? Stocks opened lower Monday and continued falling, extending Friday's sharp sell-off in reaction to the U.K.'s Brexit vote.Financial issues were hard hit. Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) both gapped down for a second day, dropping 5% and 3%, respectively.Travel bellwether Priceline (PCLN) fell 4%. Priceline skidded 11% on Friday.European banks that were hit hard Friday took additional blows Monday morning, gapping down for a second day. Deutsche Bank (DB) fell 6%, while Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) tumbled 14% on the back of a 14% drop Friday, diving to its lowest level since the financial crisis.All 30 Dow stocks were weaker, with two financial stocks -- American Express (AXP) and JPMorgan (JPM) -- down 4% each. American Express lost 5% on Friday while JPMorgan sank 7%.The Nasdaq fell 2.5%, the S&P 500 dropped 2%, and the Dow Jones industrial average was dinged for a 1.7% loss. Volume was tracking significantly lighter than Friday's hugely elevated levels, when initial reaction to the Brexit vote combined with the rebalancing of Russell indexes.Treasury Secretary Jack Lew and Secretary of State John Kerry took to the airwaves before the open to try to calm investors.The British pound was in full retreat again, trading near $1.31, a 5% drop to a 31-year lows. The euro was down to $1.10, lower by 1%. The dollar was higher by 1%.The flight to safety gained momentum, with the yield on the 10-year Treasury note falling 11 basis points to 1.47% after a 19-basis point drop Friday. The benchmark yield is approaching an all-time low of 1.43% set in 2012 as Treasury prices rally.Oil kept falling. West Texas Intermediate futures for August delivery fell 2.4% to $46.49 a barrel.IBD 50 stocks were all lower except for two defensive names: B&G Foods (BGS) and WEC Energy (WEC), a utility, which had small gains.

Brexit fallout continued Monday as U.S. stocks again followed European bourses sharply lower, with steep declines by American Express (AXP) and JPMorgan  (JPM).The major indexes closed off their intraday lows, but they still finished well in the bottom half of their session ranges. The Nasdaq sank 2.4%, the S&P 500 shed 1.8%, and the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 1.5%, with the latter two breaching their 200-day moving average lines for the first time since March.Volume was slightly lower across the board vs. Friday, according to preliminary figures, but it was still intense overall. Banks and oil stocks were among the hardest hit in the stock market today. West Texas Intermediate crude slid 2% to $46.74 a barrel, while gold prices climbed 0.5% to $1,328.90 an ounce.American Express led the Dow's decline with a 4% drop, adding to its 5% plunge in heavy volume Friday. Shares are now near four-month lows and are 29% off their 52-week high. JPMorgan fell 3%, bringing its two-session loss to 10%.Only two blue chips managed to avoid the downdraft: Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and Verizon Communications (VZ). J&J is just off a record high, while Verizon climbed past a 54.59 cup-base buy point in busy trade.The few industry groups managing small gains were all defensive in nature: utilities, food and beverage, and soap. On the IBD 50, electric utility WEC Energy Group (WEC), Dollar General (DG) and B&G Foods (BGS) eked out gains of 1% or more each.But Acuity Brands (AYI), chip designer MaxLinear (MXL) and Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) each lost about 6%, while BroadSoft (BSFT), GrubHub (GRUB) and LifeLock (LOCK) shed nearly 5% apiece.Britain's credit rating suffered downgrades following last week's Brexit vote. Standard & Poor's on Monday lowered its U.K. credit rating by two notches to AA. Fitch also cut its rating to AA.Economic data slated for Tuesday include first-quarter GDP, the S&P/Case-Shiller Home Price Index for April, and the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for June.

The stock market was sharply lower with 30 minutet to go in Monday's session as Wall Street pondered the economic implications of last week's Brexit news.Western Digital (WDC) and Seagate (STX) led the Nasdaq 100 lower, falling around 13% and 10%, respectively. American Express (AXP) and DuPont (DD) weighed on the Dow, with losses of around 4% apiece.The Nasdaq slumped 2.7%, the S&P 500 fell 2.1%, and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 1.7%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking slightly lower than Friday's levels.The put/call ratio was at 1.23 in late-afternoon trading, indicating excessive fear in the market. Fear has been seen at many market bottoms in the past.Financials were hit hard again, as the Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) slumped about 3%, bringing its two-session decline to 8%. Energy-related industry groups also lagged as benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled at $46.33 a barrel, down nearly 3%.Utilities outperformed. IBD 50 name WEC Energy (WEC) was among a small group of gainers. Shares added close to 2%. B&G Foods (BGS), Dollar General (DG) and CoreSite Realty (COR) also gained.The U.S. dollar rallied for the second straight session, and the British pound fell hard again after hitting a 30-year low Friday. The U.S. 10-year Treasury yield shed another 10 basis points to 1.46%.In the stock market today. Tyler Technologies (TYL) also bucked the downtrend, rising 2%. Breakouts don't have much of a chance in a weak market, but the tech services firm is working on a cup-with-handle base with a 160.69 buy point.Tyler is one of several strong-performing tech services firms. See who the others are with IBD Stock Checkup.Meanwhile, news of a new summer loyalty program didn't help Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG). Shares lost 3% and were down 19% year-to-date.On the downside, European discount airline Ryanair (RYAAY) faced more selling after Friday's 4% haircut. Shares lost an additional 14%.Acuity Brands (AYI) slumped nearly 6% ahead of its earnings report Wednesday before the open.

U.S. stocks followed overseas markets sharply lower Friday in reaction to Britain's shocking decision to exit the European Union. Apple (AAPL), Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan (JPM) sold off hard in the Dow industrials.The Nasdaq led the sell-off with a 4.1% drop, while the S&P 500 tumbled 3.6%, and the Dow Jones industrial average shed 3.4%. All three indexes were showed weekly losses of nearly 2%. Volume for the session swelled across the board vs. Thursday, according to preliminary data.Losers swamped winners by about a 5-1 margin on the NYSE and by 6-to-1 on the Nasdaq. The Dow was a sea of red, with losses of about 7% apiece from Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan and Caterpillar (CAT). American Express (AXP), Boeing (BA), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and IBM (IBM) sank over 5% each. Apple weighed heavily on all three indexes as it gapped down to sink 3% in brisk trade.West Texas Intermediate crude sank 5% to $47.60 a barrel, while gold prices soared nearly 5% to $1,321.70 an ounce. The 10-year Treasury yield fell 18 basis points to 1.57%.Online travel firms were the worst performers in the stock market today, as Priceline (PCLN) gapped down with a plunge of 11% to slice its 50-day and 200-day lines in fast trade. The reservation services provider received 67% of its revenue last year from the Netherlands.Rival Expedia (EXPE) sank 7% in heavy volume to a two-month low, while TripAdvisor (TRIP) lost 6%, also in rapid turnover.Banks and steel stocks also got hammered. Gold stocks were among the few gainers, as investors fled to safety.But some stocks shielded from European exposure rose. IBD 50 name Dollar General (DG) reversed upward for a 0.5% gain, and utility services provider WEC Energy Group (WEC) rose 1%. Both stocks are near all-time highs.Economic data due out Monday include the Dallas Federal Reserve Manufacturing Survey and Markit's Flash Services PMI, both for June, as well as international trade in goods for April.

Priceline (PCLN), which got the majority of its revenue came from Europe last year, took the biggest hit. Shares gapped down and plummeted 11%, slicing both the 50-day and 200-day moving…

Stocks gave back a chunk of the day's gains, despite news from the U.K. that suggested the status quo would prevail in Thursday's vote on whether to abandon the European Union.The Nasdaq nailed down a 0.8% gain after being up as much as 1.7%. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.6% and 0.7%, respectively. Volume in the stock market today ran behind Friday's pace. However, Friday was a quadruple witching day, which often boosts volume.Although bookmaker William Hill now puts the odds of Britain remaining in the EU at 83%, other factors also could have been spurring the market higher. For example, going into Monday's action, the Nasdaq and S&P 500 had lost ground in six of the past seven sessions. No trend can head the same way day after day, so a gain was due. However, whether that represented a turnaround in the short-term trend or a mere pause wasn't clear. The negative reversals in the indexes suggested that more pain could be ahead.Blue chips were solidly up. Mega-cap 3M Company (MMM), the biggest weighting in the price-weighted Dow, advanced almost 1.5% in average turnover. Although 3M is up 14% so far this year, the stock has lost some institutional support. For example, Fidelity Contrafund (FCNTX) trimmed its position in each of the past four quarters for an overall reduction of 26%.In the IBD 50, a collection of the strongest stocks in fundamentals and chart characteristics, 44 stocks rose and 6 fell. In the IBD Big Cap 20, the best of the large-cap stocks, 19 advanced and only 1 fell. The loser was utility WEC Energy Group (WEC), which retreated mildly in soft volume.

Sellers were back in the stock market Thursday, one day after the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged. The market still expects two rate hikes this year, but six Fed officials now see just one hike this year, vs. just one official back in March.Among the Dow industrials, Walt Disney (DIS) fell 1%. Its $5.5 billion theme park opened in Shanghai today. Early gainers in the Nasdaq 100 included Ctrip.com (CTRP) and Priceline (PCLN). China-based Ctrip.com, an online travel firm, rallied more than 4% intraday on strong Q1 results, but is currently up nearly 2%.The Nasdaq fell 0.7%, the S&P 500 0.5% and the Dow 0.4% on the stock market today, but significantly off session lows. Small caps also took a hit, with the Russell 2000 down 1.3%. Early data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq tracking slightly higher than Wednesday's levels. The put/call ratio spiked to 1.22 early Thursday, indicating intense investor fear.The 10-year Treasury yield is at 1.56% after falling to 1.52% intraday, the lowest since late 2012.The selling resumed in European markets overnight. The German DAX was down 0.8% in afternoon trading. London's FTSE lost 0.4%, and the Paris CAC 40 gave up 0.6%.A barrage of economic data early Thursday gave Wall Street more food for thought. Consumer prices for May were tame, jobless claims rose a bit more than expected, the Philadelphia Federal Reserve manufacturing index came in well above forecasts and homebuilder confidence was the highest since January.Kroger (KR) bucked the trend, rising nearly 3% on strong earnings.See who the leaders are in IBD's grocery store store group with IBD Stock Checkup.Elsewhere, FedEx (FDX) initially gave up 1% but is now up fractionally ahead of its earnings report, due next Tuesday. Earlier this month, the company raised its quarterly dividend 60% to 40 cents a share. FedEx is carving a flat base, but sellers have been in the stock recently, knocking it below its 50-day moving average. Lonely gainers in the IBD 50 included WEC Energy (WEC), Dollar General (DG) and B&G Foods (BGS).At the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil for July delivery fell more than 3% to $46.40 a barrel. August gold rallied 2% to $1,317 an ounce. SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) gapped up to a 52-week high.

It’s a simple fact of life: Larger conveyances offer smoother rides, be they cars, horses, ships, motorcycles or aircraft.The same tends to hold true for stocks. Hefty market capitalizations, big floats and deep-pocketed shareholders tend to provide shock absorbers for a stock during tumultuous markets.This is one of the driving reasons for IBD’s Big Cap 20 list.The feature appears every Tuesday in IBD and can be found daily under Investors.com’s Stock Lists menu.Stocks on the list must have market capitalizations of at least $15 billion. They must also pass muster with regard to EPS and Relative Strength ratings, the Sales + Margins + Return On Equity Rating, and other factors related to their chart status and balance sheet.Most Big Cap 20 names are "low beta" stocks. This means they tend to swing less than the S&P 500 on a day-to-day basis. At the top of the current Big Cap 20 list (see Feb. 23 edition), the IBD Stock Quote for Verizon (VZ) shows a Beta of 0.73. That marks it 27% less volatile than the overall market.In short, Verizon is not likely to become a hyperactive growth stock. But it still may produce solid gains during periods when the market struggles, and it is less likely to shake shareholders out with volatile action. Take this year, for instance: When the S&P 500 ended Wednesday down 4.6% for the year, Verizon showed a 9.9% gain.Here's one added perk: Many Big Cap 20 stocks also offer dividends. In Verizon’s case, the current dividend yields an annualized 4.5%.Not all Big Cap 20 stocks have low betas. No. 2 on the current list, Nvidia (NVDA), shows a beta of 1.19. It's definitely more volatile.But further down the list you’ll find AT&T (T) with a beta of 0.67, Tyson Foods (TSN) with a 0.66 beta and WEC Energy Group (WEC) with a beta of 0.56. These three big-cap stocks are up 8%, 23% and 10%, respectively, and offer dividend yields of 5.1%, 0.9% and 3.1% this year.And that’s just a quick scan through the first eight stocks on the list.Remember, you don’t just jump into any stock on the list. As with any leading stock, big-cap leaders must be passing valid buy points in strong volume, and the market must be in an uptrend. Be more cautious if you see IBD's Big Picture column noting that the uptrend is under pressure.

Oil's decline and China's woes have pushed the equities market into a deep freeze.Hardly a day passes without negative stock market news that adds ice to the market chill. They're gone from the list, replaced by defensive names, including food makers, REITs and utilities.

Defensive stocks can shine because messy markets are making money managers mortified. They are being bought on the theory they will go down less than high-flying growth stocks. And, if corporate earnings and the economy are beginning to sag, the public will continue to buy their products and services, while they might reduce their buying of expensive durable goods, such as cars or TV sets.
Defensive stocks also pay dividends that can cushion a downturn.
But investors should keep in mind that a bear market will take everything down with it. There's no such thing as a safe stock.

Among the top names in today's list is Constellation Brands (STZ), a purveyor of beer and booze. Its products could classify it as a defensive stock, but it has definite growth characteristics. It has a five-year annualized growth rate of 25%. Analysts expect 20% growth in fiscal 2016 and 14% growth in 2017.
After riding along the north side of its 50-day moving average for months, it gapped to a new high Thursday after reporting better-than-expected earnings that were 15% higher than a year earlier.
A REIT making this week's cut is Public Storage (PSA).

Public Storage owns 2,200 self-storage facilities with more than 142 million square feet of net rentable space in the U.S. and Europe plus a minority stake in PS Business Parks (PSB), which has another 28 million rentable square feet of commercial and industrial space.
It pays a dividend that is equal to an annualized yield of 2.8%.

Public Service Enterprise Group Inc.’s (PEG  -  Free Report) subsidiary — Public Service Electric and Gas Co. (PSE&G) — recently requested the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (“BPU”) to increase its electric and gas base delivery rates. If approved, the new rates will boost the company’s revenues by 1%.This filing comes as a mandate of the company’s Energy Strong program worth $1.2 billion that got approved by the New Jersey BPU in 2014.Other Details Once approved, the combined residential electric and natural gas customers' annual bill will witness a nominal rise of 1%. The company has assured customers that even after this proposed increase, residential customer bills are expected to be more than 15% lower than they were in 2010.Per management, this rate hike will enable Public Service Enterprise to recover costs that the company incurred to strengthen its electric and gas distribution systems, thereby making them more reliable. Moreover, this proposal reflects the company’s first regulatory rate review in more than eight years.Through this rate filing, Public Service Enterprise has also sought BPU approval for a rate design change, called the Green Enabling Mechanism (GEM). This new rate structure aims at separating the company’s revenues from sales volumes and thereby encourages energy efficiency.  If approved, the GEM will remove the incentive to sell more energy and will instead encourage utility investments in energy efficiency, renewables and other clean energy technologies that will benefit customers by bringing down bills and reducing carbon emissions.The company expects the new base rates as well as the GEM to come into effect from Oct 1, 2018.Our ViewIn May 2014, Public Service Enterprise announced that the New Jersey BPU approved its Energy Strong proposal to proactively protect and strengthen its electric and gas systems to withstand severe weather conditions. Per this proposal, the company aimed at significantly upgrading its infrastructure, which included adding intelligence to its system to help speed restoration during outages.Under the agreement, it was announced that PSE&G will earn an authorized return on equity of 9.75% on the first $1 billion of investment based on an accelerated recovery mechanism.  The impact of the $1-billion investment on the typical residential customer bill is expected to be approximately 2% in 2018 which will be more than offset by transitional charges stemming from deregulation that are expiring in the same time frame.For the remaining $220 million, the company aimed at filling a base rate case after Nov 1, 2017. We believe the latest rate review proposal has been filed by the company to recover this $220 million of the Energy Strong program.Notably, in March 2017, Public Service Enterprise announced plans to spend $12.3 billion for PSE&G’s baseline infrastructure program, which in turn reflects 7% CAGR growth in rate base. The latest rate reform request, if approved, will allow the company to achieve this target.Moreover, Public Service Enterprise continues to undertake several initiatives to support New Jersey Senate’s bill that requires utilities in the state to source 80% of their electricity from renewable energy by 2050. We believe to further comply with this bill, the company has included the GEM clause in the latest rate filing.Notably, in the clean energy space, the company is currently pursuing two solar initiatives, namely, the Solar Loan Program and the Solar 4 All and Solar 4 All Extension programs. In November 2016, the BPU approved a settlement providing for an extension of PSE&G’s existing solar program to construct up to 33 MW of grid-connected facilities with projected investment of approximately $80 million through May 2020.Also, the projected addition of 1,858 megawatts of new gas-fired capacity over 2017 through 2019 will help the company transform itself. Banking on these recently adopted initiatives, management expects nuclear and gas-fired generation facilities to provide more than 90% of the company’s electric output, by the end of this decade.Price PerformanceBuoyed by the solid investment plans, the company's shares have outperformed the broader industry over a year.
